para.paratext: Relevant evidence may be excluded if its probative value is substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice, confusion of the issues, or misleading the jury or by considerations of undue delay, waste of time, or needless presentation of cumulative evidence.[1] This rule mirrors Federal Rule of Evidence 403 and is interpreted accordingly by our courts.[2] The application of the rule is a matter committed principally to the sound discretion of the trial court, and will only be reviewed for abuse of discretion on appeal.[3] The exclusion of evidence is an extraordinary remedy which should be used sparingly.[4]

The Georgia Supreme Court has thus upheld the admissibility of post-incision autopsy photos as relevant to the explanation of cause of death over an exclusionary rule objection,[5] permitted the admission of photos as relevant to show the nature and extent of a victim's injuries,[6] and allowed the presentation of crime scene photos which assisted in the presentation of crime scene experts and were probative of the question of whether the victim was killed with malice.[7] Further, although gruesome, the Supreme Court allowed photographs showing where the medical examiner removed organs from the deceased and inserted rods to demonstrate the trajectory of bullets, which was relevant and probative of the fact that the victim was sitting when he was shot.[8]

In 2015, the Georgia Supreme Court examined O.C.G.A. § 24-4-403 in conjunction with the admissibility of similar transactions in State v. Jones.[9] In that case, the Court cautioned, “there is no mechanical solution for this balancing test. Instead, a trial court must undertake in each case a considered evaluation of the proffered justification for the admission of such evidence and make an independent determination of whether the probative value of the evidence is substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice, confusion of the issues, or misleading the jury or by considerations of undue delay, waste of time, or needless presentation of cumulative evidence.” The Court further opined that “a trial court's discretion to exclude evidence under the balancing test of Rule 403 is an extraordinary remedy which should be used only sparingly since it permits the trial court to exclude concededly probative evidence.” Thus, in close cases, the balance under Rule 403 should be struck in favor of admissibility.[10]

The trial court is vested with the duty to balance the probative value of evidence against any negative effects and its decision will not be disturbed unless abused. In fact, the court is within its discretion to not expressly evaluate the threshold inquiry of whether other acts are relevant where the court nevertheless excludes the evidence on the grounds that its probative value was substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice.[11]

In Parks v. State,[12] the Georgia Supreme Court held that it was error for the trial court to admit evidence of the defendant's convictions for similar crimes from 13 years before where the court held that the only reason to introduce them was to prove defendant's propensity for violence. The Court affirmed the trial court's holding the error was harmless given the substantial evidence of defendant's guilt otherwise.

Likewise, the Supreme Court held that the trial court incorrectly admitted photographs of the victim and her family, introduced by the state through the victim's husband.[13] However following federal law, reversal in that case was not warranted because the Court could not say that there was a reasonable likelihood that the defendant's substantial rights were affected by the wrongful admission.[14]

The issue of “negative effects” frequently arises in cases involving particularly gruesome evidence. In Quedens v. State,[15] the trial court admitted the victim's skeletal remains, which were laid on a table in the courtroom and examined by an expert before the jury. The prosecution contended that this evidence was necessary because the defendant contested the identity of the remains. The defendant argued that the prejudicial impact of the presence of the victim's remains in the courtroom outweighed their probative value. In affirming the admission of the evidence, the Georgia Supreme Court explained that the trial court could properly exclude relevant evidence only “if its probative value is substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice, confusion of the issues, or misleading of the jury.”[16] Noting that, in most cases, photographic evidence of a victim's remains is used to illustrate an expert's testimony, the court acknowledged, “we have generally concluded that the probative value of [such] photos exceeds their prejudicial impact.”[17] Thus, while admission of the actual skeletal remains into evidence was an unusual circumstance, it was not an abuse of discretion by the trial court because the expert witness used them to illustrate portions of the testimony.

Likewise, in Freeman v. State,[18] the Court of Appeals examined the exclusion of prejudicial evidence under the new rule and determined that the viewing in person of defendant's four-year-old son, who was wheeled into the courtroom in a stroller after his foster mother testified he was not capable of talking, walking, feeding, or toileting himself, may have been prejudicial to defendant, who was accused of child abuse by violently shaking him as an infant, causing permanent brain damage, the probative value of that evidence was not substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice, The court noted that, in criminal trials, relevant evidence is inherently prejudicial; it is only when unfair prejudice substantially outweighs its probative value that the rule permits exclusion.

The Georgia Supreme Court has explained that the exclusion of evidence under Rule 403 is an extraordinary remedy which should be used only sparingly.[19] Thus, the major function of Rule 403 is to “exclude matters of scant or cumulative probative force, dragged in by the heels for the sake of its prejudicial effect.”[20]

In Dailey v. State,[21] the Court upheld the admission of post-autopsy photographs that depicted the victim's internal injuries. The Court reasoned that the photographs were relevant in that they depicted the injuries that caused the death, and therefore their probative value was not substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice.

In United States v. Bradley,[22] the Eleventh Circuit affirmed the trial court's admission of “wealth evidence” such as photographs of defendant pharmaceutical company owner's real estate, vehicles, watercraft, and aircraft in a Medicaid fraud case[23] as probative of defendants' motive to further their lavish lifestyle through the fraud's substantial profits, “even if only slightly so.”[24] Given that the evidence was “only slightly prejudicial,” the court held that the district court did not abuse its discretion in finding the wealth evidence's probative value was not substantially outweighed by the risk of prejudice.[25] Likewise, the Georgia Supreme Court has held that Georgia's common law rule relating to the relevance of party wealth is no longer independently in force, but rather, the new rules have replaced it, and this evidence is now subject to a 403(b) analysis.[26]

The Georgia Supreme Court also found admissible testimony from a probation officer regarding the defendant's phone number for the purpose of connecting the defendant to the number. The Court reasoned that its probative value of connecting the defendant to the phone from which calls were made was not substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice.[27]

Likewise, the Supreme Court found the probative nature of testimony about prior acts of domestic violence, while highly prejudicial, tended to show that the violence was a mechanism for control of the appellant's intimate partner, and as such was admissible under a Rule 403 analysis.[28] The Court of Appeals found, in State v. Voyles,[29] that the trial court had abused its discretion when ruling evidence of similar offenses under O.G.G.A. § 24-4-417 was unfairly prejudicial, thus applying the Rule 403 balancing analysis to O.C.G.A § 24-4-417.
State v. Jones, 297 Ga. 156, 773 S.E.2d 170 (2015), citing U.S. v. Terzado-Madruga, 897 F.2d 1099, 1119, 30 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 662 (11th Cir. 1990).

State v. Dowdell, 335 Ga. App. 773, 783 S.E.2d 138 (2016), holding that the state could not introduce evidence of two prior criminal acts in a rape case, where the extrinsic acts occurred 10 years before when the defendant was a teenager and involved people the defendant knew.
Quedens v. State, 280 Ga. 355, 361, 629 S.E.2d 197 (2006) (quoting Hicks v. State, 256 Ga. 715, 352 S.E.2d 762 (1987)).
Quedens v. State, 280 Ga. 355, 361, 629 S.E.2d 197 (2006) (citing Jackson v. State, 272 Ga. 429, 531 S.E.2d 700 (2000); Thornton v. State, 264 Ga. 563, 449 S.E.2d 98 (1994)).
Freeman v. State, 333 Ga. App. 6, 775 S.E.2d 258 (2015).
Chrysler Group, LLC v. Walden, 303 Ga. 358, 812 S.E.2d 244 (2018).
State v. Voyles, 345 Ga. App. 634, 814 S.E.2d 767 (2018).
